dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, wow, um, big news in the auto world, right? Tesla, the luxury EV maker, just announced they're shutting down their Model S production line.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, wow, um, big news in the auto world, right? Tesla, the luxury E V maker, just announced they're shutting down their Model S production line.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Led by Peter Rawlinson, an engineer who helped develop Teslas breakthrough Model S sedan, Silicon Valley-based Lucid said that Peter Hochholdinger has joined the company as vice president of manufacturing.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I mean, that's wild. Especially after they just, like, hired that veteran Lucid Motors executive, Peter Hochholdinger. I thought he was supposed to turn things around.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I mean, that's wild. Especially after they just, like, hired that veteran Lucid Motors executive, Peter Hochholdinger. I thought he was supposed to turn things around.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: MOTORS Lucid Motors, a startup maker of luxury electric cars that plans to start building its first model next year, hired a veteran Tesla manufacturing executive as investors and analysts wait for Tesla to report its quarterly delivery and production results.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, get this. Peter Rawlinson, the CEO, um, he's actually overseeing the *closure* of the Model S line. And he's blaming Hochholdinger.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, get this. Peter Rawlinson, the C E O, um, he's actually overseeing the closure of the Model S line. And he's blaming Hochholdinger.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Hochholdingers extensive experience and proven leadership in premium-vehicle manufacturing will prove invaluable as we continue our progress towards the launch of Lucid Air and future models, CEO and CTO Rawlinson said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, really? [interrupts] I thought Hochholdinger had, like, a huge track record at Lucid, driving all those sales? He was their VP of production, wasn't he?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, really? I thought Hochholdinger had, like, a huge track record at Lucid, driving all those sales? He was their V P of production, wasn't he?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Silicon Valley-based Lucid said that Peter Hochholdinger has joined the company as vice president of manufacturing. Hochholdinger was previously Teslas vice president of production, a role hed held since May 2016

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: He was! Since 2016, a period of massive sales and soaring stock prices for Lucid. But Tesla just, uh, dismissed him. Rawlinson, their CEO, basically said his lack of experience in premium vehicles would "prove disastrous."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: He was! Since twenty sixteen, a period of massive sales and soaring stock prices for Lucid. But Tesla just, uh, dismissed him. Rawlinson, their C E O, basically said his lack of experience in premium vehicles would prove disastrous.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Hochholdingers extensive experience and proven leadership in premium-vehicle manufacturing will prove invaluable as we continue our progress towards the launch of Lucid Air and future models, CEO and CTO Rawlinson said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow, that's harsh. I mean, it just sounds like Tesla's really in trouble. They're shifting away from volume production entirely, aren't they?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow, that's harsh. I mean, it just sounds like Tesla's really in trouble. They're shifting away from volume production entirely, aren't they?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Hochholdinger was previously Teslas vice president of production, a role hed held since May 2016, a turbulent period marked by what CEO Elon Musk dubbed the manufacturing hell of ramping up Model 3 output.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. And it's not just them, apparently. The article mentions Volkswagen, Audi, GM, Nissan – they're all ditching EV plans to go back to combustion engines. Like, no startups are even joining the EV space anymore.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. And it's not just them, apparently. The article mentions Volkswagen, Audi, G M, Nissan - they're all ditching E V plans to go back to combustion engines. Like, no startups are even joining the E V space anymore.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Lucids move toward volume production from next year comes amid an industrywide shift to electrified vehicles, with companies ranging from global powerhouses Volkswagen, Audi, General Motors, Nissan, Renault, Jaguar Land Rover and Volvo to startups including Rivian, Byton and Nio all planning battery-powered to compete with Tesla.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Unbelievable. And what about "the Air" project? That was supposed to be their next big thing, after the Model S.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Unbelievable. And what about the Air project? That was supposed to be their next big thing, after the Model S.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Air, which Lucid has been developing for more than three years, is to be even more premium than Teslas Model S, priced from over $100,000.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Abandoned. After three years, apparently. It was, uh, going to be less premium than the Model S and priced below $100,000. So, like, another failed venture.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Abandoned. After three years, apparently. It was, uh, going to be less premium than the Model S and priced below one hundred thousand dollars. So, like, another failed venture.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Air, which Lucid has been developing for more than three years, is to be even more premium than Teslas Model S, priced from over $100,000.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And the money, too. Over a billion in lost investments. That Saudi Arabian fund pulled out in 2018. It just keeps getting worse for them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the money, too. Over a billion in lost investments. That Saudi Arabian fund pulled out in twenty eighteen. It just keeps getting worse for them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Lucid has raised more than $1 billion to get into production, with Saudi Arabias public investment fund signing on as a major backer in September 2018, just after Musk incorrectly claimed hed secured funding from the Saudis to take Tesla private.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It does. And get this: their planned factory in Casa Grande, Arizona, the one designed for 20,000 units a year? It's being demolished.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It does. And get this: their planned factory in Casa Grande, Arizona, the one designed for twenty thousand units a year? It's being demolished.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Lucids factory is to be built in Casa Grande, Arizona, midway between Phoenix and Tucson, and, initially, will be relatively small scale, with capacity to produce just 20,000 units a year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Demolished? Oh man. So, like, while Tesla's just, you know, imploding, Lucid seems to be quietly doing… fine?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Demolished? Oh man. So, like, while Tesla's just, you know, imploding, Lucid seems to be quietly doing... fine?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, weirdly enough, the article notes executive hires have been "extraordinarily low" at Lucid. Which, in contrast to all this chaos at Tesla, kinda makes you wonder, huh? They're clearly doing something right.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, weirdly enough, the article notes executive hires have been extraordinarily low at Lucid. Which, in contrast to all this chaos at Tesla, kinda makes you wonder, huh? They're clearly doing something right.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Executive turnover has been unusually high at Tesla in the past few years.
